preprocessor feature macros that change compilation of this function: HTTPS_SUPPORT, DEBUG_STATES, UPGRADE_SUPPORT
explanation: To determine whether this function uses any compiler language extensions (as prohibited by the MISRA rule), the analyzer must inspect all macros, typedefs, enums and external functions referenced in the function body and the data structures it manipulates. Macros such as mhd_assert, MHD_PANIC, MHD_DLOG, MHD_FUNC_ and the translation macro '_' commonly expand to code that can include compiler-specific builtins or extensions (statement-expressions, __attribute__, __builtin_* calls, typeof, inline asm, etc.), so their definitions must be checked. The connection and nested rq structure definitions and the state/TLS/event-loop enums/defines are required to ensure no use of extension features in types (e.g. flexible array members, GCC attributes, unusual bit-field usage) or in constant expressions. External functions called (has_unprocessed_upload_body_data_in_buffer, check_and_grow_read_buffer_space, gnutls_record_get_direction, MHD_state_to_string) must be inspected because they might be macros or inline functions that use extensions. Finally, the conditional compilation macros (HTTPS_SUPPORT, DEBUG_STATES, UPGRADE_SUPPORT) gate code paths — those alternate paths may contain extensions, so the definitions controlling them are needed to see what code actually gets compiled. Reviewing these symbols lets an analyst determine whether any part of the compiled code for this function relies on documented compiler language extensions.
